headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Georgia Grand Jury: "Perjury May Have Been Committed" In Trump Probe; Doctor: President Biden Remains Healthy, Vigorous, Fit; Salt Lake City Hosts First NBA All-Star Weekend In 30 Years. Aired 7:30-8a ET

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: They are calling your --O'NEAL:  On today's -- on today's episode you give the answer.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.(LAUGHTER) (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: AUDIE CORNISH, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Poppy Harlow joins us now from Salt Lake City, Utah. And if you peer down into the corner of your screen and you see a cheerful, smiling person waving their arms, that's her.

utterances.speaker: KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: We can actually see you in the -- in the huge camera.

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Hi.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: So we're going to be back with you later in a little bit. What are you going to be talking about?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes. We have a great lineup. So you saw the guys there -- Chuck -- Charles Barkley, Shaq, Kenny. We sat down for an interview that went nothing like I expected because that's what you get when you sit down with "INSIDE THE NBA." I feel very tall, guys. I feel very tall in that photo. I had a total ball with them.Then we're going to be joined by -- in a few minutes, actually, by Ryan Smith who is not only the owner of the Jazz, he's the founder of a big tech company called Qualtrics and a huge promoter of Utah, and what I've learned, they call the Silicon Slope. So we're going to talk about his fascinating story in the Jazz. And then the WNBA commissioner Cathy Engelbert is going to join us next hour. We're going to talk about their increase in T.V. ratings, women in sports -- yay. And she has an update -- a special update on Brittney Griner. So we have all that ahead. And then my buddy is here. Andy, come say hi. This is --

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I saw him earlier.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: -- my -- we always see him. Can he get in this shot?

utterances.speaker: ANDY SCHOLES, CNN SPORTS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Can you get in the shot?

utterances.speaker: SCHOLES
utterances.sentences: Oh, there we go.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: He's in it. He's in it.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: And then Andy is here as well.

utterances.speaker: SCHOLES
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: We always see him on T.V. from afar and he's here, so yes.

utterances.speaker: SCHOLES
utterances.sentences: It's going to be a great weekend.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SCHOLES
utterances.sentences: About 100,000 people here --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: SCHOLES
utterances.sentences: -- for some basketball. I always love 3-point competitions. That's my jam.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: That's the band Poppy will be in.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SCHOLES
utterances.sentences: I love 3-point competitions.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: But the dunk. Come on, the dunk.

utterances.speaker: SCHOLES
utterances.sentences: Oh, the dunk contest.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: He's here, right.

utterances.speaker: SCHOLES
utterances.sentences: Yes. Shaq told me it's -- like he told me last night it's kind of waning recently. HARLOW

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: SCHOLES
utterances.sentences: Well, just the star power. We don't have the big names anymore. So I look forward to 3-point competition.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Please. Oh, also Ryan Smith, the owner of the Jazz, apparently can dunk, so --

utterances.speaker: SCHOLES
utterances.sentences: That's impressive.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes, who knew?

utterances.speaker: SCHOLES
utterances.sentences: I'm pretty sure -- well, Michael Jordan can dunk.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SCHOLES
utterances.sentences: He's the owner of the Hornets. And then he -- and then he can dunk. So that's two --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SCHOLES
utterances.sentences: -- NBA owners that can dunk.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes, there's that.

utterances.speaker: SCHOLES
utterances.sentences: And it's -- you know, it's more than any NFL owners.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: It's pretty good. There you go.All right, guys, back to you.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: But it's also interesting. It's the first time, Poppy, they've had the All-Star weekend actually in Salt Lake since it -- since it first started 30 years ago.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: And I will tell you that apparently, Ryan used to sneak into this stadium and couldn't afford a ticket to the All-Star Game because it's expensive. Who can? Then now he owns a team, so how's that for you? Full-circle story coming up from here.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I love that. I can't wait to see all of these interviews. Good to see you, Andy, as well. Poppy will check back with you in a moment for all of that fun stuff.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: She said good to see you.

utterances.speaker: SCHOLES
utterances.sentences: Yes, good to see you.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: All right. But first this morning --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Andy.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: -- we're going to turn to a lot of developments that are happening in the news. The special grand jury that is investigating and investigated former President Trump in Fulton County and the actions that he took there says there was no widespread vote that took place in Georgia's results in the 2020 presidential election. That is according to the newly-released parts of their final report.Georgia's Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger says this backs up what he has been telling us all along. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: No fraud but maybe some perjury. The report says that perjury may have been committed by one or more of the witnesses who testified. The grand jury is recommending that the district attorney seek appropriate indictments because of that. The report though does not name any witnesses because they have not brought any charges yet.The Fulton County district attorney Fani Willis has not brought any of those. It remains to be seen whether or not she does.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: "Healthy, vigorous, and fit to successfully execute the duties of the presidency." Those are quotes from President Biden's doctor after his physical and -- at Walter Reed Thursday. Also, there were no findings consistent with stroke, MS, or Parkinson's disease after an extremely detailed neurological exam. Now, doctors did remove a small lesion on his chest for a biopsy and test results on that are pending.The report comes ahead of Biden's reelection intentions in the next few months.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It's remarkable. I mean, the president does not have to share his health results.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It's not legally obligated. But --

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: But in recent years it has become a very important question to voters and to political opponents.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes, and especially with Biden given he's the oldest president we've ever had and --

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: -- and is running for reelection.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: A Denver city councilmember is getting a well-deserved apology this morning after he had to crawl onto the stage of a political debate on Monday. The venue did not have any wheelchair access. And organizers asked the councilman, Chris Hinds, to raise himself onto the stage so they only had to lift his chair, which weighs 400 pounds.The facility's executive director is now apologizing after backlash saying, quote, "I deeply regret it took this incident to elevate the urgency for this change and we are committed to ensuring that no one experiences lack of access to the stage again." The councilmember also got an apology from the county clerk's office, which organizes these debates. He says he's satisfied with the response but it certainly put a highlight on the fact that they did not have access to it in the first place.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Heartbreaking news about Bruce Willis. His wife says he now has a form of dementia. Willis was diagnosed with aphasia last spring, which is the loss of ability to understand or express speech but his wife now says his condition has progressed.We're going to bring in CNN senior medical correspondent Elizabeth Cohen. Elizabeth, help us understand better this specific type of dementia.

utterances.speaker: ELIZABETH COHEN, CNN SENIOR MEDICAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Yes, Audie. I think sometimes when people hear dementia they automatically think Alzheimer's disease, which is a type of dementia but there are others as well. And what Mr. Willis has is something called frontotemporal dementia.Let's take a look at the brain and you can see the lobes that we're talking about. There is damage to neurons in the frontal lobe and also in the temporal lobe. And this kind of -- as we see with Mr. Willis, this is actually often diagnosed in the late 40s or 50s or 60s, so unlike Alzheimer's, this tends to affect younger people -- Audie.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: What does that mean for family and for how it progresses in terms of quality of life?

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: Right. So, unfortunately, it is progressive. There is no cure. So let's take a look at some of the details of this type of dementia.So it is actually nerve loss in -- as we discussed, in the front or temporal lobe. And what people -- what you can see, it kind of varies from person to person. But in general, deterioration in behavior, personality, difficulty with comprehending language, difficulty with speaking. There are no specific treatments. You can give people, for example, medicine for their depression or for their irritability, but that's kind of about it. It's basically just medicines to treat the symptoms. And it's everything from depression to unusual behavior, to changes in gait, changes in walking. It's a real wide range. It is very difficult sometimes to get a diagnosis for this type of dementia. And his family said we are just so -- obviously, they're unhappy that he's ill but they said they're so grateful to finally have a diagnosis because it allows them to move on and to think about the best ways to take care of him -- Audie.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Yes, they're bringing a lot of awareness to this.Just before you go can you talk about how common it is? This is an unusual diagnosis, is it not?

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: It is. It is less common than other types of dementia but it may be more common than we think because it does sometimes take years to get a diagnosis. And sometimes people -- even after they're gone they never got the right diagnosis. So it's very possible that more people have this than we think.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Elizabeth Cohen, thank you so much for this explanation.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Also ahead, what President Biden is now saying publicly about the mysterious objects that were shot down by the U.S. over North America and upcoming talks with China's president. We'll discuss with the chair of the Foreign Affairs Committee, Mike McCaul. He is live in Munich where the Security Conference is underway.

utterances.speaker: RYAN SMITH, OWNER, UTAH JAZZ, FOUNDER AND EXECUTIVE CHAIRMAN, QUALTRICS
utterances.sentences: No. Look, we haven't had the All-Star Game in 30 years. It's a completely new place. I mean, look around. We're the youngest state in the country. There's a lot of things -- I mean, states have a problem owning different things.The one thing we own is innovation here and you're going to see a lot of innovation. This is the first full-digital All-Star Game. It's the most tech-forward All-Star Game. And I think you're seeing a lot of hope in this state. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Hey, it's so good to be here. Thanks for coming.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I'm thrilled --

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: This is awesome.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: -- to be here.So the story goes that you used to sneak into this arena to watch the Jazz. True?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: I mean, I may or may not have once or twice, yes. But yes -- no, I know -- I know this place pretty well.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: And you couldn't afford a ticket -- because most people can't -- to an All-Star Game in '93.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Yes, for sure.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Now you own the Jazz. Can you just talk about the -- what this moment means?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: So first of all, I think it's a huge moment for the state and I think it's great timing because Utah is unbelievably -- it's just on fire right now. And for me as a kid to be here and have like our team and be such a big fan and to be back here with the Jazz with our representation --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: -- and just watch the state rallying. Like, there's so many people that want to be here who come into Utah, and it's just a good moment to shine.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You actually think Utah's gotten a bad rap. You've said that the people that branded it did -- your words, not mine -- a horrible job.What do people get wrong about this state?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: So I think -- I think -- I don't think people did a horrible job. I just think the states --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I think I read that quote.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Yes. Maybe the states --the state has completely changed over the last 20 years and I would say specifically, the last 10. I mean, we've constantly been in the top 10 for fastest-growing. But if you look, we get seven million people in here who come in here for skiing, they visit our parks, but they would always leave. And now we have this tech ecosystem that's top three in the country and it's changed the state.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I've learned it's called the Silicon Slopes. You founded Qualtrics here more than 20 years ago. You sold an $8 billion deal to SAP. You have this huge IPO.I don't think of tech when I think of Utah.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You want to change that.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Well, I think -- I think we already have. I mean, we have more IPOs in Utah than San Francisco or New York City in 2018.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: There you go.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: And, I mean, I think probably the bigger thing is this is the story that people should be looking at and those who know, know.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.Before we move on to basketball and what's happening tonight, just talk about tech in general because we've seen these sweeping layoffs across tech. You guys had to lay off about 250 workers. What is happening in tech right now?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Look, we've had an incredible run on tech, first of all. Like, we started Qualtrics in 2002, then we went through 2007, 2008, and 2009.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: And if you look since then it's been epic. And I just think we're seeing a little bit more of a right-sizing --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: -- and we're probably still not back to where we were in 2010, 2011, 2012. So it's just a little bit of the ebb and flow but we're going to be right.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So let's talk about tonight. You -- we just saw you with Dwyane Wade and you guys are going to be team captains of the celebrity game tonight. A lot of money is being donated, part of it to 5 For The Fight, your cancer charity that's raised over $50 million. What are we going to see tonight?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Well, so first of all, Team Ryan is going to take down Team Dwyane.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Oh, really?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Yes. That's -- I mean, he's been -- he's been in the gym. Like, this is -- this is -- and he slow-plays it. He's like hey, by the way, I've got a 10But it's just an incredible event. He's such a good sport because --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: -- I mean, he's an NBA top-75 player and here I am, like, just a guy shooting, so --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: But you -- can you really dunk?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Yes. I think I'm -- I mean, at this age, yes, a little bit.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You think so?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You didn't do so well trying to dunk in front of D. Wade the other day.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Yes, I -- it was off the back of the rim the whole time.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: But --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: There's that.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: -- we'll see.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: We have bad days.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Hey, there's adrenalin.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: We have bad days.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So on a more serious note, when you -- so I -- you wanted to buy my team, the Minnesota Timberwolves, apparently, and your wife was like, we are Utah. We have -- good thing you listened to her.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So you end up acquiring the Jazz in a transaction that was really meaningful because you talk about it as stewardship. Can you tell me what -- tell our viewers what Adam Silver, thecommissioner, told you when you got the team?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: -- whether it's religious or political, or universities, everyone agrees on the Jazz.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: In your first press conference you came out and you said this franchise is going to be actively anti-racist. What does that mean? Why did you do it? How do you do it today?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Well, I think -- I think that in America and across the world you're seeing a great divide. I think we're further apart maybe than we've been in the past. And I think you need to be proactive and it's not something that you can just sit back and be reactive for. So it's something we think about all the time from who we hire to the programs we start, and to letting --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: The scholarships.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: The scholarships. I mean, we -- for the last three years every Jazz win we've offered a full-ride scholarship for a minority student. And if you look at 120 wins and 120 scholars, it starts with education.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: So in everything we're doing we're saying hey, look, this is -- this is who we are as an organization and how do we show up, and what message are we sending to the community.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Quickly before we go, you're sort of M.O. in building a big tech company was to build something great you have to tear down something good. You've made some unpopular decisions with the Jazz in terms of trading all-stars. Questions about coaching decisions. How do you think about that as you apply it to the NBA?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: You know, I think we -- I have a -- I have a sign in my office that says "Tune out the noise and play the long game." And, like, we're playing the long game here. We want to have an incredible run. The Jazz are the second-winningest franchise over the last 30 years and we're trying to be that over the next 30 years.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: We look --

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: And so --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: -- forward to watching it.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Ryan.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Thanks for having me on.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Have a great weekend.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Yes, it's a nice spot here.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes. Thanks for having us to your second home.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Guys, there is a full weekend of All-Star events on our sister channel TNT. It's all leading up to the All-Star Game Sunday night. Back to you guys.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: OK. I know you guys were saying earlier -- I still like the dunk contest and I'm excited to see that. But Poppy, we have been talking here about --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: -- John Fetterman this morning and the conversation that he's brought. Something that I was reading that I thought was amazing about the Utah Jazz is they actually have a vice president of player wellness who does mental health checks in -- with players on the team and bringing that conversation --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Ryan is smiling.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Oh, really?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes. I don't know if we can get his shot.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I didn't even know that. That's pretty great that you guys do that.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Well, it's a -- it's a big part of the world, especially if you're an athlete.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Especially if you're an athlete.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes. Good for you. Good for you.Kaitlan always teaching me things I didn't even know. I love that they do that, too, guys.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes, all right.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: We'll get back to you in a little bit.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Well, excited to see much more of your interviews there, Poppy. Can't wait to get back. And CNN THIS MORNING continues right now.Good morning, everyone. Audie Cornish is here at the desk with us this morning. Don has the day off. Poppy, as you can see there, is in Utah for the NBA All-Star Game. We have a lot of great moments from there with Charles Barkley. I can't wait to see those. But first, we're going to talk this morning about what we are seeing here, which is new surveillance videos that show sparks flying from the wheels of the same train that later crashed just a short time later and unleashed that toxic disaster in Ohio. It could be a major clue for investigators. We're going to hear from the head of the EPA about the massive cleanup that's underway as families are worried about their health.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Plus, President Biden says the mysterious flying objects recently shot down do not appear to be spy balloons, but will Republicans be satisfied with that answer? We'll speak to the chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, Michael McCaul. And this --(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) O'NEAL:  What do people do when you walk in the bank?

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Oh, they better run to -- run to me.O'NEAL:  (Laughing).

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: When they -- when I walk in the bank if that manager's sitting there when I get there -- man, you better meet me at the door.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Nothing was off-limits -- nothing. I got a chance to sit down with three members of the legendary "INSIDE THE NBA" crew as we head into All-Star weekend right here in Salt Lake City.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: But first, we're going to start with the families in East Palestine, Ohio -- East Palestine, Ohio who are complaining this morning of headaches, pain in their throats. That comes two weeks after a train loaded with toxic chemicals crashed and burned in their small town. Now they're wondering why were they allowed to go back home.The Biden administration has deployed federal medical experts to assess just how dangerous the area is for people as the massive cleanup is very much still underway. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
